reference.title: Making content accessible
reference.shortdesc: DITA provides many elements and attributes that are specifically designed make content more accessible.

section.p: Many common types of content are not accessible to all readers in all scenarios. For example, an image cannot be rendered by a screen reader, and a video cannot be rendered in many format. DITA includes markup features designed to convey alternate versions of this content to all readers.
section.draft-comment: This is initial draft content meant as a starting point to see how we want this content organized. For things like the alt element and longdescref element, we should be reusing content from the element ref rather than effectively redefining the element here - likely reusing the full short description.

dlentry.dd: The alt element is available inside of images as a way to specify alternate text.

The longdescref element is a reference to a textual description of a graphic or object. It is intended for situations where alternate text is not sufficient to explain the content. Processors can handle the reference by turning the graphic or object into a link, or by making the extended description available to accessibility tools such as a screen reader.

Within an image map, each defined area of the image can specify a cross reference. Whether or not the cross reference actually provides a URI reference, the text within that cross reference is intended to function as alternate text or hover text for that area of the image.

section.p: While DITA provides the markup to enable these accessibility features, it is up to DITA processors and rendering formats to handle them properly. For example, when rendering an image for HTML5, any alternate text must be rendered using the alt attribute for the image to be considered accessible.
